results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this film Kenneth and some fellow travellers visit the Grampians showing the varied scenery across the mountainous ranges and the valley, groups of people relaxing and enjoying natural surrounds as well as hiking and gathering for a picnic.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:07:00 title card ‘Our Grampians’ starts us off travelling along a country road where we see the sign to Halls Gap and other local towns, followed by a sign for “Hotel Bellfield” and a spot of golf.

00:00:02:00 ‘Splitter Falls’ sign appears ahead of more views of the mountainous range, roads and the valley below.
00:04:12:00 a very long waterfall.

00:04:57:00 a group of tourist overlooling the hills from a high vantage point.

00:05:13:00 a photographer setting up a spectacular looking shot of people sitting on rocks.

00:06:37:00 toasting bread on an open fire and the sign ‘New scenic track to McKenzie Falls’.

00:09:27:00 women holding a bunch of wildflowers one of whom sports a classic 40’s headscarf style.

00:10:21:00 we see a tree being prepared for felling by two mean using a double ended saw followed by a logging truck.

00:11:14:00 sign to ‘Wonderland’ followed by a large group of people trekking up a rocky incline, taking rests on the rocks, climbing narrow ravines and finally looking out from the top.

00:15:07:00 the travellers stand around a fire with a billy-can, cooking lambchops and bread.

00:17:12:00 a farmer and his tractor from a close view and pink tinged clouds.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 130]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the Gadsden children of 1939 at camp, playing ball games, swimming in a river, dressing up for an impromptu pageant in the bush and playing water polo in the river.

The film then changes dramatically to scenes of the State wide bushfires which devastated many parts of regional Victoria on 13 January 1939 and known as ‘Black Friday’.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:23:00 flames in the bush, onlookers
00:01:49:00 sequence of scenes scanning the aftermath of the fires

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughte. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia, with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures a roadtrip to South Australia showing several ports and towns and the landscapes and ocean views along the way.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:15:00 title card ‘Exploring South Australia’ using a Shell (Gas and Oil) roadmap of SA
00:00:22:00 the Balmera Post Office with signs reading ‘Post and Telegraph Office’ and ‘Money Order and Commonwealth Savings Bank’
00:00:31:00 a town street with a large truck loaded with full hessian sacks followed by views of roses in the median strip gardens
00:01:32:00 Mrs Rankine holds some very large grapefruit
00:02:10:00 the travellers enjoy some public gardens
00:02:00:00 a ‘To Adelaide’ road sign on a flooded road, alongside some boats
00:03:20:00 filming from a punt that takes the travellers and cars across a waterway
00:05:00:00 sign reading ‘Port Augusta: Change here for Quorn Alice Springs’ followed by views of the rail station
00:05:20:00 street scenes with pedestrians, cars and buses
00:05:35:00 a long pipeline travels alongside a road in which Mrs Rankine, in a wonderful navy blue suit, sunglasses and cream ‘Maryjane’ style shoes, stands by the car taking in the views followed by two travellers on a motorcycle (motorbike)
00:06:13:00 the Whyalla Post Office followed by quiet street scenes including motorists and motorbike riders, an Orlando Wines advertising sign, lovely older buildings such as the Hotel Spencer and a great example of a 1940s or 1950s style small truck parked outside.
00:06:45:00 Mrs Rankine stands on a balcony of the hotel
00:06:57:00 a steam train carrying what appears to be aggregate crushed rock for road construction comes into view and shortly after, workers release the load into trackside rock and gravel piles, a fisherman and his bike on the pier and the rock being loaded onto the ship by way of a conveyor belt system
00:08:58:00 Mrs Rankine sits atop a very large pipeline, fanning flies away from her face
00:09:28:00 lengthy views of industrial works and cargo loading facilities
00:11:51:00 a lone blue-tongue lizard
00:12:18:00 the family car sits on top of a rise overlooking grassland and the sea, a ship, a town and in the foreground, an unusually low electricity pole and wiring
00:13:05:00 a ‘Port Lincoln’ sign on a building followed by scenes of the town, the bays, bobbing boats, public flowerbeds and 1940s and 1950s style cars, trucks and houses
00:14:53:00 the Pier Hotel with Mrs Rankine on a balcony and then in a window knitting with the blue and green sea in the background
00:15:15:00 scenes around the foreshore, out over the water, yachts, small boats and jettys and grassy shorelines
00:16:20:00 Mrs Rankine on shore in the blustery winds
00:16:55:00 a rail crossing on a sandy road with a ‘Commonwealth Roads’ sign warning of a ‘£50 penalty’
00:17:27:00 a wonderful ageing and long pier with a lighthouse at the end
00:17:42:00 a building bearing the name Port Pirie followed by views of the town and port, including a tugboat pulling a large ship into dock
00:18:15:00 another ship, named Pioneer Reef New York
00:18:18:00 a closer view of one of the tugboats followed by the Rankine family car parked on a dusty road
00:18:40:00 four big draught horses pulling a plough and then seven pulling a cultivator
00:19:07:00 Port Broughton Post Office with a sign for the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and then the Hotel Broughton
00:19:25:00 Mrs Rankine sits on a seat outside the hotel in front of a stained glass window sign for the ‘Parlor’ (interestingly, the American version of spelling), which would have been the hotel’s ladies parlour when women were not allowed in the public bar of a hotel
00:19:44:00 the Point Broughton War Memorial
00:19:58:00 a friend with their cat
00:20:05:00 a roadsign for Port Victoria followed by son-in-law Bob Wootten and grandson on a pier, who then join Mrs Rankine and Bettye (Rankine) Wootten
00:20:55:00 sign for Kadina flashes by and a train carriage, named ‘Pelican’ which was part of the ‘Bluebird Railcars’ that travelled around South Australia at the time; passengers board the carriage while luggage is loaded from a truck parked alongside
00:21:29:00 Kenneth’s grandson in his stroller and some quick scenes around the town

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film captures the building of a dam at ‘Mooltunya’, the Gadsden family farm in country Victoria. It begins with spectacular hailstones but primarily captures the construction of a dam.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:22:00 a handful of large hailstones.
00:02:59:00 earthworks for dam construction

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows tugboats assisting ships into the piers at the Port of Melbourne and stars the “James Paterson” boat on which Kenneth is filming. The scenes in the reel show a lost world of shipping and the manual labour of port operations. The reel ends with the ‘James Paterson’ tugboat at the dock.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:30:00 title card ‘Pushing and Pulling’ and “starring James Paterson and Norman C. McBain”. Shortly after, we see a tugboat named ‘James Paterson’.

00:03:31:00 scenes of the workings of the tugboats in assisting ships in and out of port, stoking the engine fires, ships crews looking down from the great height of their vessels whilst the tugboats manoeuvre around them.

00:03:45:00 shots of boats and water and a large ship ‘Pipiriki’ leaving a pier and being towed by a tugboat from where Kenneth is filming, presumably on the ‘James Paterson’; we see shots of a harbour and ships and boats passing by as well as one the tugboat operator at the wheel.

00:04:07:00 we see the ship ‘Sanoma’ followed by men working lines on the tugboat alongside the ship.

00:07:55:00 ‘Melbourne Star’ ship, the ‘Wombat’ tugboat and ‘River Murumbidgee’.

00:09:15:00 we see a close up of rope work by the crew of the ‘Clan Macaulay’.

00:10:05:00 shows a great closeup shot of workers chatting on the tugboat.

00:11:50:00 a good shot of one of the dockside piers.

00:12:13:00 sequence from this point shows a ship hoisted into dry dock - Kenneth uses shots of the boat stop signal, a dry dock supply shop and the pier to emphasise the dry dock surrounds.

00:13:00:00 the scene changes to night time on the water followed by some passenger ships.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 28]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows a visit to ‘Mooltunya’, which was Ronald and Jess Gadsden’s farm in regional Victoria. Members of the Gadsden family and friends circle participate in the various activities at the farm, including helping with farm work.

Toward the end of the film there are scenes of yachts sailing around a bay which is likely to be Port Phillip Bay.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:43:00 the ‘Mooltunya’ farmgate
00:03:23:00 younger family members trying out horses
00:05:00:00 painting the farm house roof
00:06:11:00 spray painting the house atop a ladder across the roof
00:08:04:00 a new ‘David Brown 880’ tractor and slasher being used for slashing in the paddock
00:11:10:00 a younger Gadsden using the tractor and slasher at speed
00:18:42:00 installing a windmill by being at the very top
00:20:57:00 cows seeking shade under a tree
00:21:03:00 scene changes for sailing
00:23:08:00 hay making at the farm

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures the wedding of the filmmaker’s daughter, Bettye Rankine to Robert (Bob) Wootton, both of whom would feature in Kenneth’s films. Of particular note are the opening sequences of the reel which show Kenneth’s interest in devising creative and clever titles. Kenneth frames shots of the soon to be bride and groom separately against a tree blowing in the breeze on a sunny day, as singles followed by ‘Bettye Rankine and Bob Wootton in Our Wedding’ as the main title. Kenneth also uses his artistic sub-titles to separate sequences in the reel as well as his lingering shots of flowers (a device which he used regularly throughout his films). Highlights of the reel include the 1940s style of wedding and the wedding fashions of the era. Scenes at the wedding reception show some of the customs of day such as drinking an obligatory glass of sherry (usually upon arrival) and hosting the reception in the family home. Footage also includes the couple enjoying life with their first child some time later. The wedding segment ends with the couple shot in the same frame, now together and married as compared to the single shots of the opening title sequences.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:30:00 title cards, ‘Bettye Rankine and Robert Rankine in’ followed by, ‘Our Wedding’ which follow a preliminary sequence of the bride and groom shot individually.

00:00:34:00 scenes showing the preparation for the wedding reflects the more simple style of weddings of the era (late 1940s from the appearance of the car models). Although the wedding dress is of a lustrous satin fabric with a long train, it is a simple design compared to the prevailing current styles and the bride and groom are attended by only one attendant each.

00:01:28:00 shot of the full train of the wedding dress.

00:02:00:00 lovely look at Kenneth and Bettye on way to the car framed in the Rankine family driveway and garden.

00:02:16:00 scene showing the family were in a position to hire a car and chauffeur for the occasion.

00:02:28:00 Bettye Rankine in her wedding veil framed in the car window.

00:03:58:00 scenes at the church include a closeup of the bridal bouquets.

00:04:06:00 we see Mrs Rankine for the first time in a shot with Bettye and Kenneth outside the church.

00:04:55:00 the bridal couple arrive at their table at what seems to be a private home rather than a reception venue.

00:04:59:00 framed shot of guests drinking sherry at the reception.

00:05:20:00 Kenneth shows the bridal party and guests laughing and relaxed and the happy groom kissing the bride.

00:05:45:00 reception scenes give us a glimpse into the prevailing celebratory fashions and customs of the day - suits and hats and the occasional fur.

00:06:56:00 the wedding sequence ends with a formal title card ‘The End’ after we see the couple shot in the same frame, now together as compared to the single shots of the opening title.

00:07:05:00 title ‘And Now Kenneth Robert as Blue Eyes’ begins a sequence about the Wootton’s first child. Kenneth sets up a beginning sequence where we see Bettye and Bob and Mrs Rankine gazing at above at the sky looking (as we realise) for the stork to deliver the baby.

00:07:30:00 Kenneth Robert has arrived and there are lots of shots of him as a very happy baby in the sunny family garden.

00:08:04:00 Kenneth devises some scenes where Bob Wootton is polishing a car that suddenly turns in to a larger car that he then shows off to Mrs Rankine and Bettye. Cars feature in Kenneth’s films including a scene here where he and Bob reverse the wide cars down the narrow driveway which was typical of the house style at the time.

00:12:18:00 a title for the baby at one year old showing height, chest, weight and number of teeth. We immediately see footage of what is likely to be the baby christening at what appears to be a country church.

00:13:15:00 showing us the baby now crawling on a rug in the family garden.

00:14:28:00 the baby is sitting playing with a ‘Kool Mints’ tin, playing with water, clapping with his mother and being tickled; the baby being fed what appears to be sugar on a plastic spoon gripped in his teeth to cover his nose, sitting on his stroller and learning to walk between his parents;

00:17:10:00 the baby walks independently and soon after is tottering around the garden.

00:17:46:00 with another flower to separate scenes, we see the baby sliding around the garden on a spade being held by his father, running with a pull-along toy, riding around on a broom; playing with a balloon that bursts, looking quite confident with the camera, playing with a spinning top.

00:19:37:00 title card for the baby at two which includes height and weight followed by a brief shot of the toddler ending with a final flower.

00:06:56:00 the wedding sequence ends with a formal title card ‘The End’ after we see the couple shot in the same frame, now together as compared to the single shots of the opening title.

00:07:05:00 title ‘And Now Kenneth Robert as Blue Eyes’ begins a sequence about the Wootton’s first child. Kenneth sets up a beginning sequence where we see Bettye and Bob and Mrs Rankine gazing at above at the sky looking (as we realise) for the stork to deliver the baby.

00:07:30:00 Kenneth Robert has arrived and there are lots of shots of him as a very happy baby in the sunny family garden.

00:08:04:00 Kenneth devises some scenes where Bob Wootton is polishing a car that suddenly turns in to a larger car that he then shows off to Mrs Rankine and Bettye. Cars feature in Kenneth’s films including a scene here where he and Bob reverse the wide cars down the narrow driveway which was typical of the house style at the time.

00:12:18:00 a title for the baby at one year old showing height, chest, weight and number of teeth. We immediately see footage of what is likely to be the baby christening at what appears to be a country church.

00:13:15:00 showing us the baby now crawling on a rug in the family garden.

00:14:28:00 the baby is sitting playing with a ‘Kool Mints’ tin, playing with water, clapping with his mother and being tickled; the baby being fed what appears to be sugar on a plastic spoon gripped in his teeth to cover his nose, sitting on his stroller and learning to walk between his parents;

00:17:10:00 the baby walks independently and soon after is tottering around the garden.

00:17:46:00 with another flower to separate scenes, we see the baby sliding around the garden on a spade being held by his father, running with a pull-along toy, riding around on a broom; playing with a balloon that bursts, looking quite confident with the camera, playing with a spinning top.

00:19:37:00 title card for the baby at two which includes height and weight followed by a brief shot of the toddler ending with a final flower.
description_for_label:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures the wedding of the filmmaker’s daughter, Bettye Rankine to Robert (Bob) Wootton, both of whom would feature in Kenneth’s films. Of particular note are the opening sequences of the reel which show Kenneth’s interest in devising creative and clever titles. Kenneth frames shots of the soon to be bride and groom separately against a tree blowing in the breeze on a sunny day, as singles followed by ‘Bettye Rankine and Bob Wootton in Our Wedding’ as the main title. Kenneth also uses his artistic sub-titles to separate sequences in the reel as well as his lingering shots of flowers (a device which he used regularly throughout his films). Highlights of the reel include the 1940s style of wedding and the wedding fashions of the era. Scenes at the wedding reception show some of the customs of day such as drinking an obligatory glass of sherry (usually upon arrival) and hosting the reception in the family home. Footage also includes the couple enjoying life with their first child some time later. The wedding segment ends with the couple shot in the same frame, now together and married as compared to the single shots of the opening title sequences.

00:00:34:00 scenes showing the preparation for the wedding reflects the more simple style of weddings of the era (late 1940s from the appearance of the car models). Although the wedding dress is of a lustrous satin fabric with a long train, it is a simple design compared to the prevailing current styles and the bride and groom are attended by only one attendant each.

00:01:28:00 shot of the full train of the wedding dress.

00:02:28:00 Bettye Rankine in her wedding veil framed in the car window.

results.title: Fred's Films. ARC Cement Works Geelong [excerpt]
results.brief_description: The A.R.C Cement Works, Geelong, in the early 1960s is faithfully captured here by Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker. Fred has recorded a moment in industry that - post 2000 - no longer exists, that of the use of powerful steam locomotives. With the ‘loco’ pulling people on this occasion and not cement, this is most likely a farewell celebration to the use of the engines at the Plant. Fred’s titles tell us it is “3ft 6 Gauge” and there is a close up on an engine name-plate indicating this engine had come all the way from Manchester and another “1903 Leeds, Hudswell Clarke & Co Ltd No. 646”, a smaller black engine that had obviously been a working machine at the Cement Works for many a year. There is a sense of this being quite an occasion with many people visiting to take pictures and enjoy the plumes of steam from these majestic work horses.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is more whimsical in approach than the family based footage seen in other films, as reflected by the title ‘Open Road Open Sky’. In the opening scene we see Kenneth a fellow traveller wandering along country roads as well as shots of roads into the distance and the skies overhead. Further into the reel we see the Sherbrooke Forest, the ‘Burnham Beeches’ and ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’. There are shots of several animals such as emu and echidna as well as quite a bit of birdlife and Kenneth’s favourite shots of flowers and trees. The reel ends with Kenneth walking away from the forests and an end title shot.

Selected sequence list:

00:00:27:00 title ‘Open Road Open Sky’, Kenneth and a fellow traveller wandering along country roads.

00:01:00:00 large power poles along country roads, a few examples of country houses.

00:01:47:00 kangaroos and peacocks.

00:02:45:00 Kenneth walks along a road with his camera.

00:03:14:00 an emu, echidna and a wallaby come into view.

00:04:15:00 close up of Kenneth filming behind his camera followed by ‘Burnham Beeches’ mansion and estate in Sherbrooke Forest and the ‘Alfred Nicholson Memorial Gardens’.

00:06:31:00 birdlife inlcuding storks and lyrebirds.

00:07:44:00 Indigenous rider on horseback, waving at the camera whilst he rounds up horses, camels and Shetland ponies on grassland.

00:08:07:00 brolgas (filmed only from neck down only so difficult to be certain).

00:10:03:00 a quick shot of a woman behind the camera.
